questions.text:
Which of the following statements correctly describes nitroimidazoles?


	Metronidazole inhibits bacterial DNA synthesis by interacting directly with DNA.
	Metronidazole is a prodrug converted to its active form by the bacterial nitroreductase enzyme.
	Secnidazole is one of the shortest-acting nitroimidazoles.
	Metronidazole inhibits the PFOR enzyme, which damages DNA in protozoa.
	Resistance occurs through the activation of nitric oxide free radicals.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

Statements 1, 2 and 4 are correct regarding nitroimidazoles

Nitroimidazoles

MOA
  • Prodrug is converted to active form through nitro group reduction inside the bacteria(Statement 2) → formation of nitric oxide free radicals → causes DNA damage→ inhibits replication(Statement 1)
  • Inhibits PFOR enzyme (pyruvate ferritin oxido reductase) in protozoa → causing DNA damage(Statement 4)

Drugs
  • Metronidazole
  • Ornidazole
  • Tinidazole
  • Satranidazole
  • Secnidazole: longest acting drug
  • Other: Benznidazole, Nifurtimox, Nitazoxanide

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of abdominal pain and loose stools for the past two weeks but no h/o fever. He has recently returned from a vacation to Nepal. Physical examination reveals tenderness in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. Stool testing shows mucoid stool with elevated white cell counts. What is the drug of choice for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Metronidazole

Explanation:

The patient presents with symptoms (abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and abdominal tenderness) consistent with amoebiasis, a parasitic infection caused by E. histolytica. Metronidazole is the drug of choice. The history of travel to a region with poor sanitation (Nepal), mucoid stools, and elevated white cell counts supports this diagnosis.

Metronidazole

Coverage

Broad spectrum anaerobes (Bacteroides, Clostridium, Fusobacterium, Peptococcus, etc.)

Uses
  1. Giardiasis (in HIV-positive patients)
  2. Entamoeba histolytica → Amebic dysentery & amebic liver abscess
  3. Trichomonas vaginalis
  4. Bacterial Vaginosis
  5. Dracunculus (guinea worm)
  6. Gardenella / bacterial vaginosis
  7. Empiric intra-abdomina and soft tissue anaerobic infections
  8. H. pylori gastritis (combined with proton pump inhibitor)
  9. Prophylaxis for colorectal surgery
  10. Fulminant C.difficile infection (IV metronidazole + oral vancomycin)
  11. Mild to moderate Crohn's disease

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presented to the clinic with foul-smelling diarrhoea and abdominal cramps for the past week. A stool examination revealed giardia cysts. After starting appropriate treatment, she returned a few days later, complaining of severe nausea, vomiting, headaches, and flushing after the farewell party. Which of the following is not a side effect associated with the medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tendon rupture

 

Explanation:

  • The clinical findings of the patient (foul-smelling stool, abdominal cramps), along with the stool examination, indicate giardiasis which is most likely treated with metronidazole experienced a disulfiram-like reaction after drinking alcohol during the party.
  • Common side effects include a metallic taste, neurotoxicity (peripheral neuropathy), and dark urine, while tendon rupture is a side effect of fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin).

Adverse effects of Metronidazole

Side effects
  • Metallic taste, intensely bitter (Option B)
  • Headache, nausea, dry mouth (most common)
  • Vomiting, diarrhoea, and abdominal distress
  • Dysuria, cystitis, and a sense of pelvic pressure
  • Dizziness, vertigo,
  • Neurotoxicity: Peripheral neuropathy, numbness, paresthesias, ataxia (Option C)
  • Brown color urine (Option A)
  • Urticaria, flushing, and pruritus ( rare cause of Stevens-Johnson syndrome)

Drug Interaction
  • Inhibitor of CYP enzymes
  • Disulfiram-like effect: abdominal distress, vomiting, flushing, headache or psychosis with alcoholic beverages during or within 3 days of therapy.
  • Precipitate lithium toxicity
  • Prothrombin time prolongation with warfarin (anticoagulant).

Contraindications
  • CNS diseases
  • Severe hepatic disease
  • First trimester of pregnancy

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive male presents to the clinic with a two-week history of profuse, watery diarrhoea and weight loss. His CD4 count is 150 cells/mm³, and stool examination reveals oocysts. What is the drug of choice used for treating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Nitazoxanide

Explanation:

  • The patient has HIV with CD4 <200 and presents with chronic watery diarrhoea and oocysts in stool, suggestive of Cryptosporidium parvum infection.
     
  • Nitazoxanide is the drug of choice for cryptosporidiosis in immunocompetent individuals, and it is also used in immunocompromised patients, though its effectiveness may be reduced.
     
  • ART (antiretroviral therapy) is essential for immune reconstitution in such patients for optimal recovery.
     

Cryptosporidiosis in HIV Patients

Feature

Details

Causative Agent

Cryptosporidium parvum (protozoan parasite)

Common Symptoms

Profuse watery diarrhoea, weight loss, abdominal cramps

Stool Findings

Acid-fast oocysts

Risk Factors

CD4 count <200 cells/mm³

Treatment of Choice

Nitazoxanide

Adjunctive Measures

ART initiation/improvement, hydration, nutritional support

 

Benznidazole (Option A):
Incorrect. Used for Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi), not for cryptosporidiosis.
 

Nifurtimox (Option B):
Incorrect. Also used for Chagas disease, not for Cryptosporidium infections.
 

Paromomycin (Option D):
Incorrect. An aminoglycoside with some activity against Cryptosporidium but less effective than nitazoxanide. Sometimes used in refractory cases or as adjunct.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding bacterial resistance against nitroimidazoles?

choices.text: Increase efflux pump activity to remove nitroimidazoles from the cell.
Alter the structure of ribosomal subunits to prevent nitroimidazole binding.
Produce enzymes that inactivate nitroimidazoles before they can enter the cell.
Reduce the expression of nitroreductase enzymes needed to activate nitroimidazoles.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Reduce the expression of nitroreductase enzymes needed to activate nitroimidazoles.

Explanation: 

Bacteria reduces the expression of nitroreductase enzyme to resist nitroimidazole 

Resistance in Nitroimidazoles

1.

Reduced nitroreductase enzyme expression (Option D)

↓

Nitroimidazoles (such as metronidazole) cannot activate in their active form.

↓

It prevents drug activation and stops the formation of the reactive nitroso group within the bacterial cell.

2. Lower levels of PFOR and ferredoxin. (less common)

questions.text:
Rearrange the following steps in the correct sequence based on the mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones:

1. Inhibits DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.

2. DNA replication and transcription are hindered.

3. Bacterial cell division is disrupted.

4. Bacterial DNA supercoiling and strand separation are affected.

5. Bacterial cell death occurs.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A)1, 4, 2, 3, 5

Explanation:

 

Mechanism of action of fluoroquinolones:

Mechanism of Action of Fluoroquinolones

Step

Detail

Inhibition of DNA Gyrase and Topoisomerase IV

Fluoroquinolones specifically inhibit DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, which are critical for the maintenance of DNA structure. DNA gyrase alleviates DNA supercoiling ahead of the replication fork, while topoisomerase IV is involved in decatenation, which is the separation of replicated DNA.

Disruption of DNA Supercoiling and Strand Separation

The inhibition of these enzymes results in an accumulation of positive supercoils ahead of the replication fork and strand breaks in the DNA. This disrupts DNA replication and transcription processes by preventing the unwinding of DNA for these processes to occur.

Hindrance of DNA Replication and Transcription

With disrupted DNA replication and transcription, bacterial cells cannot synthesize new RNA or proteins, leading to a halt in growth and reproduction. Without proper DNA replication, the cell cannot reproduce, and without proper transcription, protein synthesis is blocked.

Disruption of Bacterial Cell Division

Due to the halted DNA replication and transcription, bacterial cell division is impaired. As bacteria need to replicate their DNA to divide, the inability to do so leads to cell cycle arrest.

Bacterial Cell Death

The failure in replication and transcription eventually causes bacterial cell death due to accumulated DNA damage and the inability to produce essential cellular components, including proteins.
  • Fluoroquinolones work primarily by interfering with bacterial DNA replication through inhibition of DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.
     
  • These drugs are bactericidal, meaning they directly kill bacteria, unlike bacteriostatic antibiotics that only inhibit bacterial growth.
     
  • Their broad spectrum makes them effective against a variety of gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, including those that cause respiratory and urinary tract infections.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about second-generation fluoroquinolones is false?

choices.text: They have a broader spectrum of activity compared to first-generation fluoroquinolones.
They inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV.
They have a shorter half-life compared to first-generation fluoroquinolones.
They can cause QT prolongation as a side effect.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) They have a shorter half-life compared to first-generation fluoroquinolones.

Explanation:

Second-generation fluoroquinolones typically have a longer half-life than first-generation fluoroquinolones and require less frequent dosing.

 

First Generation

Second Generation

Drugs

 

Mnemonic: New COP has Small Lite Machine Gun
  • Norfloxacin
  • Ciprofloxacin
  • Ofloxacin
  • Pefloxacin
  • Sparfloxacin
  • Levofloxacin
  • Moxifloxacin
  • Gemifloxacin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Good oral absorption
  • Moderate half-life
  • Good oral absorption
  • Longer half-life(Option C is the false statement)
  • Better tissue penetration

Mechanism of Action

Inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase

Inhibit bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV(Option B)

Spectrum

Effective against Gram-negative bacteria

Broader spectrum, including Gram (+ve), Gram (-ve) and Atypical pathogens.(Option A)

Uses
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Prostatitis
  • Respiratory infections (e.g.Pneumonia)
  • Skin infections
  • Complicated UTIs

Side Effects
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Diarrhea
  • Dizziness
  • QT prolongation(Option D)
  • Tendonitis
  • CNS effects
  • Phototoxicity
  • Peripheral neuropathy

Contraindications
  • Pregnancy
  • Children
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Same as first generation
  • Patients with cardiac arrhythmias

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with flu-like symptoms, including fever, malaise, and cough. Upon further questioning, he reports recent contact with animal hides during his work at a tannery. Chest X-ray revealed a widened mediastinum. Blood cultures are drawn, and the patient is to be started on antibiotics. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ciprofloxacin

Explanation:

The given clinical vignette suggests anthrax and ciprofloxacin, which is a first-generation fluoroquinolone that is effective against it. It is the first-line treatment for anthrax, particularly in cases of inhalational anthrax or systemic dissemination.

Ciprofloxacin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Good oral absorption
  • Bioavailability ~70%,Moderate half-life (~4-5 hours)
  • Widely distributed in tissues and body fluids
  • Renal excretion

Uses
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Prostatitis
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa (DOC)
  • Anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) (DOC)
  • Gastrointestinal infections (e.g., traveller's diarrhoea)
  • Bone and joint infections

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, diarrhoea).
  • CNS effects (headache, dizziness).
  • Tendonitis and tendon rupture.
  • Photosensitivity.

Contraindications
  • Pregnancy
  • Children (due to potential for cartilage damage)
  • Myasthenia gravis (can exacerbate muscle weakness)

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of productive cough, fever, and shortness of breath. Chest X-ray reveals consolidation in the right lower lobe consistent with community-acquired pneumonia. What is the most appropriate initial antibiotic therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Levofloxacin

Explanation:

Levofloxacin is a Second Generation Fluoroquinolone Antibiotic with excellent coverage against typical and atypical pathogens commonly associated with community-acquired pneumonia. It is recommended as initial therapy for patients with moderate to severe pneumonia who require hospitalisation.

 

Levofloxacin

Pharmacokinetics
  • Good oral absorption
  • Bioavailability ~99%
  • Longer half-life (~6-8 hours)
  • Widely distributed in tissues and body fluids
  • Renal excretion.

Uses
  • Community-acquired pneumonia (DOC)
  • Acute bacterial sinusitis
  • Chronic bronchitis exacerbation
  • Second-line drug for TB
  • Urinary tract infections
  • Prostatitis
  • Skin and soft tissue infections
  • Effective against atypical pathogens (e.g., Mycoplasma, Chlamydia, Legionella

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, diarrhoea)
  • CNS effects (headache, dizziness)
  • Tendonitis and Tendon rupture.
  • QT interval prolongation
  • Photosensitivity

Contraindications
  • Pregnancy and lactation.
  • Children and adolescents (due to potential for cartilage damage)
  • Myasthenia gravis (can exacerbate muscle weakness)
  • Patients with a history of tendon disorders
  • Cardiac arrhythmias (due to risk of QT prolongation)

questions.text: Which of the following is the longest-acting fluoroquinolone?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Sparfloxacin

Explanation:

Sparfloxacin is considered the longest-acting fluoroquinolone (Half-life: 19 Hours), but it is not used due to safety concerns, particularly related to cardiac arrhythmias.

questions.text: Which of the side effects is not associated with fluoroquinolones?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Alopecia

Explanation:

Alopecia is not an adverse effect of fluoroquinolones

Adverse effects of fluoroquinolones:

  • Gastrointestinal disturbances (nausea, diarrhoea).
  • CNS effects (headache, dizziness).
  • Tendonitis and tendon rupture.(Option A)
  • QT interval prolongation.(Option B)
  • Photosensitivity.(Option C)
  • Potential for exacerbation of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female has been complaining of dysuria, increased frequency of urination, and mild lower abdominal discomfort for the past three days. She reports no fever, chills, or flank pain, and she has no known drug allergies. A urine dipstick test in the clinic shows positive nitrites and leukocyte esterase, indicating a possible mild, uncomplicated UTI. What is the most appropriate initial antibiotic treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cotrimoxazole

Explanation:

Cotrimoxazole, a combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, is an effective and commonly used treatment for uncomplicated UTIs. It is effective against a broad range of uropathogens, including many strains of E. coli.

Cotrimoxazole is generally well-tolerated and has a favourable resistance profile, making it an appropriate choice for this patient.

Cotrimoxazole

Type

Competitive Inhibitor of DHPS (PABA analogues)

Mechanism of Action

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) ⟶ Inhibit Dihydrofolate Reductase and Dihydropteroate Synthase ⟶ Disruption of Folate Synthesis ⟶ Inhibition of DNA, RNA, and Protein Synthesis ⟶ Impaired Bacterial Cell Growth and Division ⟶ Accumulation of Cellular Damage ⟶ Bacterial Death.

Uses
  • Urinary tract infections (DOC for mild cases)
  • Respiratory tract infections
  • GIT Infections
  • Prevention and treatment of Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia in immunocompromised patients

Side Effects
  • Nausea and Vomiting
  • Diarrhoea
  • Rash
  • Hypersensitivity reactions (including Stevens-Johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis)
  • Blood dyscrasias (e.g., neutropenia, thrombocytopenia)

Special Points
  • Contraindicated in patients with folate deficiency
  • Use with caution in pregnant women, infants, and individuals with G6PD deficiency
  • Increased risk of hyperkalemia with potassium-sparing diuretics

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding nitrofurantoin:


	Is primarily used for the treatment of systemic infections.
	Works by damaging bacterial DNA and ribosomal proteins.
	Is well absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and reaches high concentrations in urine.
	Is safe for use in patients with significant renal impairment.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2 and 3

Explanation:

Nitrofurantoin

Type

Urinary Antiseptic

Pharmacokinetics
  • Absorption: Rapidly absorbed from the GI tract (Food Increases Absorption)(Statement 3)
  • Distribution: High concentration in urine(Statement 3)
  • Metabolism: Minimal hepatic metabolism
  • Excretion: Excreted unchanged in urine, not recommended for use in patients with significant renal impairment (CrCl < 60 mL/min).

Mechanism of Action

Nitrofurantoin ⟶ Bacterial Reduction to Reactive Intermediates ⟶ Damage to Bacterial DNA and Ribosomal Proteins(Statement 2) ⟶ Disruption of DNA Replication, Transcription, and Translation ⟶ Inhibition of Bacterial Cell Growth and Division ⟶ Bacterial Death

Uses
  • Treatment of uncomplicated urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Prophylaxis for recurrent UTIs
 

Not effective for pyelonephritis or prostatitis

Side Effects
  • Pulmonary reactions (acute and chronic)
  • Brown Urine
  • Hemolysis in G6PD deficiency
  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Peripheral neuropathy
